content: The Act is titled the "Elementary and Secondary School Library Media Resources, Training, and Advanced Technology Assistance Act." Its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Act aims to enhance academic achievement by providing students with access to updated school library materials, advanced media centers, and trained specialists. It also supports acquiring resources for students, specialists, and teachers, while ensuring specialists have the tools for developing students' information literacy and critical thinking skills. Effective coordination of resources is also a key goal. The Act aims to enhance academic achievement by providing students with access to updated school library materials, advanced media centers, and trained specialists. It supports acquiring resources for students, specialists, and teachers, while ensuring specialists have the tools for developing students' information literacy and critical thinking skills. Effective coordination of resources is a key goal to ensure collaboration between school library media specialists, teachers, and administrators in developing curriculum-based instructional activities for students. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section on school library media resources, providing state allotments and outlining state applications for funding. The State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary to receive funding under section 3701, detailing how they will use needs assessment and poverty data to allocate funds for school library media improvement. They should also coordinate Federal and State funds for library, technology, and professional development activities to assist local educational agencies and schools. The State educational agency will use funds to improve school library media resources, provide training for specialists, and promote resource-sharing among schools. They will also develop standards for integrating new technologies into school curricula to enhance students' information literacy and critical thinking skills. The State educational agency will evaluate activities by local educational agencies under this subpart to determine the need for technical assistance and continued funding. State educational agencies receiving funds under section 3701 can reserve up to 3 percent for technical assistance, dissemination of information on effective school library programs, and administrative costs. Local educational agencies will be evaluated for the need for assistance and funding under this subpart. State educational agencies receiving funds under section 3701 must allocate funds to local educational agencies based on need for school library media improvement and poverty levels. "SEC. 3706. LOCAL ACTIVITIES." A local educational agency receiving a local allocation can use the funds for acquiring school library resources, incorporating advanced technology into curricula, facilitating resource-sharing, providing professional development for school library specialists. The local educational agency can use funds for acquiring school library resources, incorporating technology into curricula, facilitating resource-sharing, and providing professional development for school library media specialists. Additionally, the funds aim to foster collaboration between school library media specialists and teachers/administrators. "SEC. 3707. ACCOUNTABILITY AND CONTINUATION OF FUNDS." Local educational agencies receiving funding under this subpart can continue to receive funding for 2 additional fiscal years and beyond if they show an increase in access to school library resources and well-trained library media specialists in elementary and secondary schools.
